text: A role for <extra_id_0> RanBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the release of <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from the nuclear pore complex in a terminal step of nuclear export .

We recently developed an assay in which nuclear export of the shuttling transcription factor NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T cells ) can be reconstituted in permeabilized cells with the GTPase <extra_id_0> Ran <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the nuclear export receptor <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
We have now used this assay to identify another export factor .

After preincubation of permeabilized cells with a <extra_id_0> Ran <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant that can not hydrolyze GTP ( RanQ69L ) , cytosol supports NFAT export , but <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Ran <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone do not .

The RanQ69L preincubation leads to accumulation of <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the cytoplasmic periphery of the nuclear pore complex ( NPC ) in association with the <extra_id_0> p62 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex and <extra_id_0> Can <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> Nup214 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
RanGTP - dependent association of <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with these nucleoporins was reconstituted in vitro .
By biochemical fractionation and reconstitution , we showed that <extra_id_0> RanBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> restores nuclear export after the RanQ69L preincubation .
It also stimulates nuclear export in cells that have not been preincubated with RanQ69L .

<extra_id_0> RanBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as well as <extra_id_0> Ran <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding domains of the cytoplasmic nucleoporin <extra_id_0> RanBP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promote the release of <extra_id_0> CRM1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from the NPC .

Taken together , our results indicate that RanGTP is important for the targeting of export complexes to the cytoplasmic side of the NPC and that <extra_id_0> RanBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and probably <extra_id_0> RanBP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are involved in the dissociation of nuclear export complexes from the NPC in a terminal step of transport .
